questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding Vulval Intraepithelial Neoplasia (VIN)?

options.label: A
options.text: It is primarily associated with bacterial infection.

options.label: C
options.text: HPV infection is not associated with VIN.

options.label: D
options.text: >50% of cases progress into vulvar cancer.

questions.correct_answer: B. Smoking is an etiological factor.
questions.explanation:
Etiology
  • HPV infection (HPV DNA found in 80% VIN lesions) (Option C)

→ Most common serotype - HPV 16

  • Other STDs - HSV, HIV
  • Cigarette smoking (Option B)
  • Immunosuppression
  • Lichen sclerosus or other chronic dermatological conditions

Classification
  • Vulvar LSIL: Self-limited, not precancerous
  • Vulvar HSIL (formerly called Usual VIN): Multicentric and multifocal disease
  • Differentiated VIN: Precursor to most vulvar SCC

Clinical features
  • The majority of patients are asymptomatic
  • Non-specific symptoms like pruritus, burning and pain are seen in some patients.

HSIL= high-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion; LSIL= low-grade squamous intraepithelial lesion

questions.text: A 68 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a lump in the vulvar area. On examination, a lesion is noted on the labia majora. A biopsy of the lesion confirms vulvar squamous cell carcinoma. Which of the following is not a risk factor for vulvar carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
HPV infection:(Option C)

  • The most significant risk factor for vulvar carcinoma is infection with Human papilloma Virus (HPV), particularly high-risk serotypes such as HPV 16 & 18 (option C).
  • 50-75% of invasive vulvar cancers are associated with high risk HPV infections.

Smoking:(Option A)

  • Women who smoke and have a history of HPV infection have a 35 fold greater risk of developing vulvar cancer.

Vulvar Intraepithelial Neoplasia:

  • VIN is a precancerous condition, of which 10% of cases progress into Vulvar cancer

Chronic Immunosuppression:

  • HIV infection and organ transplantation.

Chronic dermatological conditions: (Option D)

  • Lichen sclerosus:Differentiated VIN is a precursor to keratinizing squamous cellcarcinoma and is strongly associated with lichen sclerosus.
  • Lichen sclerosus is a skin condition that causes itchy white patches on the genitals or other parts of the body

questions.text: Which of the following subtypes of squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva is most commonly associated with lichen sclerosus and typically occurs in postmenopausal women?
questions.explanation:
Warty/Basaloid vSCC

Keratinizing vSCC

Age group

Seen in younger women

Seen in older women

Risk factors

HPV infection (16 & 18),
Smoking,
Immunosuppression

Chronic dermatological conditions such as lichen sclerosus

Association with

Usual Vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia (HSIL)

P53 mutant differentiated vulvar intraepithelial neoplasia

Lesion

Multifocal

Unifocal

Prognosis

Better

Worse

questions.text: A 68 y/o female presents with a vulvar lesion on her labia majora. It measures 0.8 cm and has been present for several weeks. She reports persistent itching. What is the MOST appropriate investigation for this patient?
questions.explanation:
Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the vulva

Site
  • Labia majora is the most common (60%).
  • Clitoris 2nd most common (15%).
  • Most common in 50-70 years age group

Presentation
  • Exophytic (outward-growing) and ulcerative (open sore) growth.

Symptom
  • Pruritus (most common): Often associated with an itch-scratch cycle.
  • Cancer cachexia (weight loss and muscle wasting).
  • Cancer pain.

Spread
  • Primarily spreads through the lymphatic system.
  • Vulvar lymphatics cross over at the midline, especially within 2 cm of the midline.
  • The inguinofemoral lymph nodes are the most commonly involved group.
  • Lymph node involvement significantly affects prognosis.

Investigations
  • Excisional biopsy (IOC): For lesions < 1 cm in size. Complete lesion removal and histological assessment, including invasion presence and depth. (Option C)
  • Incisional biopsy: For lesions ≥ 1 cm in size. (Option D)
  • Wedge biopsy.
  • Keyes punch biopsy.
  • Sentinel lymph node biopsy: Assess lymph node involvement, particularly the inguinofemoral nodes.

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication of sentinel lymph node biopsy in vulvar cancer?

options.label: A
options.text: Tumor is located on the labia majora.

options.label: B
options.text: Tumor is smaller than 4 cm in diameter.

options.label: C
options.text: Tumor invades > 1 mm into the stroma.

questions.correct_answer: D. Clinically suspicious groin lymph nodes.

questions.text: A 68-year-old woman presents with a 3 cm ulcerated lesion on the left labia majora. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma. Physical examination reveals two palpable, mobile lymph nodes in the left groin, each measuring approximately 1 mm in diameter. What is the most likely FIGO stage of her vulvar cancer?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Invasive Vulvar Cancer

Stage 1

Limited to vulva.

1a

Tumor ≤ 2 cm, stromal invasion ≤ 1 mm, no nodal metastasis (Option A)

1b

Tumor > 2 cm, stromal invasion > 1 mm with negative nodes (Option B)

Stage II

Tumor of any size with extension to adjacent perineal structures (1/3 lower urethra, 1/3 lower vagina, anus) with negative nodes

Stage III

Tumor of any size with extension to upper ⅔ vagina, upper ⅔ urethra, bladder, or rectum.

IIIa

Regional LN ≤ 5 mm (Option C)

IIIb

Regional LN > 5 mm

IIIc

Regional LN with extracapsular spread.

Stage IV

  

IVa

Tumor invades any of the following:

  1. upper urethral and/or vaginal mucosa, bladder mucosa, rectal mucosa, or fixed to the pelvic bone, or
  2. Fixed or ulcerated inguinofemoral lymph nodes. (Option D)

IVb

Distant metastasis, including pelvic lymph nodes

questions.text: A 68y/o woman presents with a 3 cm vulvar lesion. Biopsy confirms invasive squamous cell carcinoma with a depth of invasion of 1.5 mm. Her inguinal lymph nodes are clinically negative. What is the most appropriate treatment?

options.label: A
options.text: Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy

options.label: B
options.text: Wide local excision with sentinel lymph node biopsy

options.label: D
options.text: Simple vulvectomy without lymph node assessment

questions.correct_answer: A. Radical vulvectomy with bilateral inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy
questions.explanation:
Treatment of Tumor Stages of Vulval Cancer

Stage 1

  

1a (Option B)
  • Wide local excision with a 1-cm margin is performed for the probable cure.

1b
  • Radical resection of the primary tumor and inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy (LAD).
  • Central lesion: B/L LAD
  • Lateral lesion (> 2 cm from midline): U/L LAD.

Stage II
  • Radical vulvectomy + B/L LAD
  • Positive LN involvement in HPE - Must do pelvic LAD or pelvic LN radiotherapy.

Stage III
  • Radical partial or total vulvectomy and either SLNB or inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.
  • Postoperative adjuvant radiation (4000-5000 Rads over 5 weeks) directed to both the groins and the pelvis.

Stage IV
  • Treated with chemotherapy or radiotherapy
  • Chemotherapy: 5-FU, mitomycin C
  • Other agents used are Methotrexate, bleomycin, and trastuzumab.

questions.text: A 68 Y/o female presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a noticeable lump in the vulvar region. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma of the vulva. the growth is limited to the vulva with no clinically palpable groin nodes. Imaging studies reveal no distant metastasis. Which of the following statements most accurately reflects the 5-year survival rate for this patient?

options.label: A
options.text: The 5-year survival rate is less than 30%

options.label: B
options.text: The 5-year survival rate is between 30% and 50%

options.label: C
options.text: The 5-year survival rate is between 50% and 70%

options.label: D
options.text: The 5-year survival rate is between 70% and 90%

questions.correct_answer: D. The 5-year survival rate is between 70% and 90%
questions.explanation:
FIGO staging

5-year survival rate

Stage I & II (no lymphatic involvement)

70-90% (Option D)

Stage III (inguinofemoral lymph node involvement)

30-50% (Option B)

Stage IV (tumor with regional spread)

≤30% (Option A)

questions.text: A 20-year-old woman with a history of in utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES) presents with a mass in the upper third of the anterior vaginal wall. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

options.label: A
options.text: Squamous cell carcinoma of the vagina

options.label: B
options.text: Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina

questions.correct_answer: B. Clear cell adenocarcinoma of the vagina
questions.explanation:
Vaginal Carcinoma

Etiology
  • Human papillomavirus (HPV) infection; HPV 16 is most common.
  • In utero exposure to diethylstilbestrol (DES)
  • Chronic vaginal irritation or inflammation.
  • Previous cervical or vulvar cancer.
  • Vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia
 

General population

DES-exposed women during pregnancy

Most Common Site

Upper third of the vagina, particularly the posterior wall.

Upper third of the vagina, particularly the anterior wall.

Most Common Histological Type

Squamous cell carcinoma (Option A)

Clear cell adenocarcinoma (Option B)

Clinical Features
  • Painless vaginal bleeding and abnormal discharge (M/C symptom)
  • Post-coital bleeding
  • Vaginal mass or ulcer
  • Pelvic pain
  • Dyspareunia (pain during intercourse)

questions.text: A 25 y/o woman presents with a history of abnormal Pap test results. Colposcopy reveals a well-defined, white lesion in the upper third of the vagina. Biopsy confirms the diagnosis of vaginal intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN). What is the most likely stage of this patient?
questions.explanation:
Staging of Vaginal Carcinoma

Stage

Characteristics

0

Carcinoma in situ, Intraepithelial neoplasia (VAIN) (Option A)

I

Cancer is limited to the vaginal wall.

II

Cancer has spread to the subvaginal tissue but not to the pelvic wall. (Option B)

III

Cancer has spread to the pelvic wall and/or regional lymph nodes. (Option C)

IVA

Tumor invades bladder and/or rectal mucosa and/or direct extension beyond the true pelvis. (Option D)

IVB

Spread to distant organs.

questions.text: A 60 y/o woman presents with intermittent vaginal bleeding for the past 3 months with a past history of hysterectomy. Pelvic examination reveals a 1.5 cm mass confined to the lower third of the vagina. Biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.correct_answer: A. Radical vaginectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
questions.explanation:
Management of vaginal carcinoma

Stage

Location

Treatment

Stage I

Upper 1/3rd

Surgery: Partial vulvectomy, radical hysterectomy (if uterus present), and B/L pelvic lymphadenectomy.

Middle 1/3rd

Surgery: Radical vulvectomy + B/L inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy
or Radiation: External beam, brachytherapy, or combination

Lower 1/3rd

Stage II

Any

Radiation alone (Preferred): Combination of External beam & brachytherapy

Stage III & IVA

Any

Radiation: Usually the primary treatment, often combined with chemotherapy (especially cisplatin)
Stage IVA: Pelvic exenteration &/or Radiation

Stage IVB

Any

Chemotherapy: Considered for metastatic disease

Supportive Care: Palliative care.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman has been diagnosed with SCC arising from the Bartholin gland following a biopsy after she presented with complaints of unilateral swelling in the vulvar area. Which of the following is an indication for bartholin gland biopsy?

options.label: C
options.text: Solid mass arising from Bartholin gland

questions.explanation:
Bartholin gland carcinoma
  • Maybe adenocarcinomas, SCC, or transitional cell carcinoma

Clinical features
  • Painless vulval mass
  • Perineal pain
  • Dyspareunia
  • Spreads to ischiorectal fossa and pelvic nodes

Investigations
  • MRI
  • Bartholin biopsy: Indications include,
    • Woman over 40 years
    • Recurrent cyst/abscess
    • All solid masses

Treatment
  • Radical vulvectomy + Ipsilateral/bilateral groin dissection
  • Pre/post-operative chemoradiation

questions.text: A 66 Y/o woman presents with complaints of persistent pain, and a visible lump in her vulvar region. On examination, the gynecologist notes a raised lesion on the labia majora. A biopsy is performed, and the results are indicative of malignancy. Which of the following is the most common subtype of vulvar cancer?

A 72y/o woman presents with a vulvar lesion for the past 6 months. She reports persistent pruritus and occasional bleeding from the lesion. On examination, a 2 cm ulcerated lesion is found on the labia majora. A biopsy confirms squamous cell carcinoma. Which lymph nodes are MOST commonly involved in the lymphatic drainage and spread of vulvar carcinoma?
questions.explanation:
Lymphatic drainage of the vulva

Location of Lesion

Primary Drainage Site

Notes

Lateral Vulva

Ipsilateral superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

Vulvar lymphatics do not cross the labiocrural folds.

Within 2 cm of Midline

Either superficial inguinal lymph node group.

Lesions in this area may spread to either side.

Clitoris and Upper Labia

Drain directly to the deep femoral nodes.

  

Entire Vulva (Distal Third of Vagina)

Superficial inguinal node group

Lymph travels to the deep femoral lymphatics and then through the node of Cloquet to the pelvic lymph nodes (meaning distant metastasis). (Option C)

questions.text: A 68 Y/o woman presents with a 6-month history of persistent vulvar itching and burning. She reports noticing a red, velvety rash on her vulva that occasionally oozes. On physical examination, there is an erythematous and eczematous lesion on the vulva. Biopsy of the lesion reveals large cells with abundant cytoplasm in epithelium. Which of the following is most likely the diagnosis?
questions.correct_answer: B. Paget's disease of the vulva
questions.explanation:
Paget’s disease of vulva
  • Most common extramammary Paget’s disease, originating from apocrine glands and proliferates into the epithelium.
  • 10-20% of people are associated with invasive Paget’s disease or adenocarcinoma of vulva.
  • Symptoms: Erythematous chronic skin lesions associated with pruritus, burning and pain. Multifocal well-demarcated velvety erythematous plaques, more commonly seen on labia majora.
  • Biopsy of the lesion shows paget’s cells (large cells with abundant cytoplasm) in the epithelium

Treatment

  • Non-invasive disease: lesions are resected by wide local excision with 1-2 cm margin.
  • Invasive disease: Radical partial vulvectomy with/without inguinofemoral lymphadenectomy.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman presents with complaints of persistent vulvar itching and a non-healing lesion on her vulva. On PE, a thickened, whitish plaque and ulceration are noted on the labia majora. Histopathology reveals atypical squamous cells confined to the epithelium with marked basal atypia and abnormal keratinisation as shown below. Which of the following is the patient suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Normal vulva

  • Lined by stratified squamous epithelium

Vulvar LSIL
  • Seen in younger women (option B)
  • Etiology: HPV effect
  • Flat lesions with condyloma
  • Self limited, not precancerous

Histology:

 

 

  • Mild atypical cells in the lower third of epithelium
  • Koilocytes in the upper layer

Vulval HSIL
  • Formerly called usual VIN (option A&C)
  • Seen in younger women
  • Etiology: HPV infection, STDs, immunosuppression, smoking
  • Multicentric & multifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Atypical squamous cells in all layers of epithelium
  • Extensive parakeratosis
  • Koilocytic changes in the upper layer.

Differentiated VIN
  • Seen in older, postmenopausal women (option D)
  • Etiology: Lichen sclerosus and other chronic dermatological conditions
  • Unicentric and unifocal disease
  • Precancerous condition

Histology:

 

 

  • Prominent nucleoli
  • Basal atypia with acanthosis, dyskeratosis

Vulvar LSIL
  • Self-limited condition.
  • Not treated unless symptomatic.

Vulvar HSIL and differentiated VIN
  • Precancerous conditions.
  • All lesions should be treated.
  • Treatment options:
  • Wide local excision
  • Laser ablation
  • Topical 5-FU or imiquimod
